docs.title: ARVOS Documentation
docs.text:
Professional sensor streaming platform for iPhone and Apple Watch

Turn your iPhone (and optional Apple Watch) into a research-grade sensor platform with LiDAR, cameras, IMU, ARKit pose tracking, and wearable motion sensing.

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Start
docs.text:
Get started in 30 seconds with the Web Viewer (no installation required):

cd arvos-sdk/web-viewer
./start-viewer.sh
# Scan QR code with iPhone → Done!

Or use the Python SDK for custom applications:

pip install arvos-sdk
python examples/01_quickstart.py

docs.title: 📱 What ARVOS Streams
docs.text: ARVOS captures and streams high-quality sensor data from your iPhone and Apple Watch:

docs.title: iPhone Sensors
docs.text:
• 📷 Camera: 30 FPS @ 1920x1080 RGB video
  • 🔍 LiDAR/Depth: 5 FPS 3D point clouds with confidence maps
  • 📊 IMU: 100-200 Hz accelerometer + gyroscope + gravity
  • 🧭 ARKit Pose: 30-60 Hz 6DOF camera tracking with quality flags
  • 📍 GPS: 1 Hz location data (outdoor)

docs.title: Apple Watch Sensors (Optional)
docs.text:
• ⌚ IMU: 50-100 Hz wearable accelerometer + gyroscope + gravity
  • 🧭 Attitude: Quaternion + pitch/roll/yaw angles
  • 🚶 Motion Activity: Classification (walking, running, cycling, vehicle, stationary)

All sensors are nanosecond-synchronized for research-grade data collection.

docs.title: 🌐 7 Streaming Protocols
docs.text:
ARVOS supports multiple streaming protocols to fit different use cases:

Protocol Best For Port Status WebSocket General purpose 9090 ✅ Complete gRPC High performance, research 50051 ✅ Complete MQTT IoT, multi-subscriber 1883 ✅ Complete HTTP/REST Simple integration 8080 ✅ Complete Bluetooth LE Low bandwidth, cable-free N/A ✅ Complete MCAP Stream Robotics research 17500 ✅ Complete QUIC/HTTP3 Ultra-low latency 4433 ✅ Complete

→ Protocol Comparison Guide

docs.title: Clients API
docs.text: Client classes for connecting to ARVOS servers.

docs.title: ArvosClient
docs.text:
WebSocket client for connecting to ARVOS servers.

from arvos import ArvosClient

client = ArvosClient()

docs.title: connect(uri: str, timeout: float = 10.0)
docs.text:
Connect to an ARVOS server.

Parameters: - uri (str): WebSocket URI (e.g., "ws://192.168.1.100:9090") - timeout (float): Connection timeout in seconds (default: 10.0)

Example: 

await client.connect("ws://192.168.1.100:9090")

docs.title: disconnect()
docs.text:
Disconnect from server.

Example: 

await client.disconnect()

docs.title: run()
docs.text:
Main receive loop - call after connect().

Example: 

await client.run()

docs.title: Callbacks
docs.text:
Same callback interface as ArvosServer:

client.on_connect = lambda: print("Connected")
client.on_imu = lambda data: print(f"IMU: {data}")
client.on_camera = lambda frame: print(f"Camera: {frame}")
# ... etc

docs.title: connected: bool
docs.text: Connection status.

docs.title: messages_received: int
docs.text: Total messages received.

docs.title: bytes_received: int
docs.text: Total bytes received.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import asyncio
from arvos import ArvosClient

async def main():
    client = ArvosClient()

    client.on_imu = lambda data: print(f"IMU: {data}")
    client.on_camera = lambda frame: print(f"Camera: {frame.width}x{frame.height}")

    await client.connect("ws://192.168.1.100:9090")
    await client.run()

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: Data Types
docs.text: Complete reference for all ARVOS sensor data types.

docs.title: IMUData
docs.text:
IMU sensor data (accelerometer, gyroscope, gravity).

@dataclass
class IMUData:
    timestamp_ns: int
    angular_velocity: Tuple[float, float, float]  # rad/s (x, y, z)
    linear_acceleration: Tuple[float, float, float]  # m/s² (x, y, z)
    magnetic_field: Optional[Tuple[float, float, float]]  # μT (x, y, z)
    attitude: Optional[Tuple[float, float, float]]  # roll, pitch, yaw (rad)

    # Properties
    timestamp_s: float  # Timestamp in seconds
    angular_velocity_array: np.ndarray
    linear_acceleration_array: np.ndarray

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
async def on_imu(data: IMUData):
    print(f"Timestamp: {data.timestamp_s}s")
    print(f"Angular velocity: {data.angular_velocity}")
    print(f"Acceleration: {data.linear_acceleration}")

    # Access as numpy arrays
    accel = data.linear_acceleration_array
    gyro = data.angular_velocity_array

docs.title: GPSData
docs.text:
GPS location data.

@dataclass
class GPSData:
    timestamp_ns: int
    latitude: float  # degrees
    longitude: float  # degrees
    altitude: float  # meters
    horizontal_accuracy: float  # meters
    vertical_accuracy: float  # meters
    speed: float  # m/s
    course: float  # degrees

    # Properties
    timestamp_s: float
    coordinates: Tuple[float, float]  # (lat, lon)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
async def on_gps(data: GPSData):
    lat, lon = data.coordinates
    print(f"Position: {lat:.6f}, {lon:.6f}")
    print(f"Altitude: {data.altitude:.1f}m")
    print(f"Accuracy: ±{data.horizontal_accuracy:.1f}m")

docs.title: PoseData
docs.text:
ARKit 6DOF camera pose.

@dataclass
class PoseData:
    timestamp_ns: int
    position: Tuple[float, float, float]  # meters (x, y, z)
    orientation: Tuple[float, float, float, float]  # quaternion (x, y, z, w)
    tracking_state: str  # "normal", "limited_*", "not_available"

    # Properties
    timestamp_s: float
    position_array: np.ndarray
    orientation_array: np.ndarray

    # Methods
    is_tracking_good() -> bool

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
async def on_pose(data: PoseData):
    print(f"Position: {data.position}")
    print(f"Orientation: {data.orientation}")
    print(f"Tracking: {data.tracking_state}")

    if data.is_tracking_good():
        # Process pose data
        pass

docs.title: CameraFrame
docs.text:
Camera frame data.

@dataclass
class CameraFrame:
    timestamp_ns: int
    width: int
    height: int
    format: str  # "jpeg", "h264"
    data: bytes  # compressed image data
    intrinsics: Optional[CameraIntrinsics]

    # Properties
    timestamp_s: float
    size_kb: float

    # Methods
    to_numpy() -> Optional[np.ndarray]  # Decode to RGB array

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
async def on_camera(frame: CameraFrame):
    print(f"Frame: {frame.width}x{frame.height}")
    print(f"Size: {frame.size_kb:.1f} KB")

    # Decode to numpy array
    img = frame.to_numpy()
    if img is not None:
        # Process image
        pass

docs.title: DepthFrame
docs.text:
Depth/LiDAR frame data.

@dataclass
class DepthFrame:
    timestamp_ns: int
    point_count: int
    min_depth: float  # meters
    max_depth: float  # meters
    format: str  # "raw_depth", "point_cloud"
    data: bytes  # PLY or raw depth data

    # Properties
    timestamp_s: float
    size_kb: float

    # Methods
    to_point_cloud() -> Optional[np.ndarray]  # Parse PLY to (N, 6) array

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
async def on_depth(frame: DepthFrame):
    print(f"Points: {frame.point_count}")
    print(f"Depth range: {frame.min_depth:.2f} - {frame.max_depth:.2f}m")

    # Parse point cloud
    points = frame.to_point_cloud()
    if points is not None:
        xyz = points[:, :3]  # 3D positions
        rgb = points[:, 3:]  # RGB colors

docs.title: WatchIMUData
docs.text:
Apple Watch IMU data.

@dataclass
class WatchIMUData:
    timestamp_ns: int
    angular_velocity: Tuple[float, float, float]  # rad/s (x, y, z)
    linear_acceleration: Tuple[float, float, float]  # m/s² (x, y, z)
    gravity: Tuple[float, float, float]  # m/s² (x, y, z)

    # Properties
    timestamp_s: float
    angular_velocity_array: np.ndarray
    linear_acceleration_array: np.ndarray
    gravity_array: np.ndarray

docs.title: WatchAttitudeData
docs.text:
Apple Watch attitude data.

@dataclass
class WatchAttitudeData:
    timestamp_ns: int
    quaternion: Tuple[float, float, float, float]  # x, y, z, w
    pitch: float  # radians
    roll: float   # radians
    yaw: float    # radians
    reference_frame: str

    # Properties
    timestamp_s: float
    quaternion_array: np.ndarray

docs.title: WatchMotionActivityData
docs.text:
Apple Watch motion activity.

@dataclass
class WatchMotionActivityData:
    timestamp_ns: int
    state: str  # "walking", "running", "cycling", "vehicle", "stationary", "unknown"
    confidence: float  # 0.0 - 1.0

    # Properties
    timestamp_s: float

docs.title: HandshakeMessage
docs.text:
Device information and capabilities.

@dataclass
class HandshakeMessage:
    device_name: str
    device_model: str
    os_version: str
    app_version: str
    capabilities: DeviceCapabilities

docs.title: DeviceCapabilities
docs.text:
Device sensor capabilities.

@dataclass
class DeviceCapabilities:
    has_lidar: bool
    has_arkit: bool
    has_gps: bool
    has_imu: bool
    has_watch: bool
    supported_modes: List[str]

docs.title: Python SDK API Reference
docs.text: Complete API reference for the ARVOS Python SDK.

docs.title: ArvosServer
docs.text:
Main WebSocket server class.

from arvos import ArvosServer

server = ArvosServer(host="0.0.0.0", port=9090)

docs.title: start()
docs.text:
Start the WebSocket server.

await server.start()

docs.title: stop()
docs.text:
Stop the server and close all connections.

await server.stop()

docs.title: print_qr_code()
docs.text:
Display QR code for easy connection.

server.print_qr_code()

docs.title: get_websocket_url() -> str
docs.text:
Get the WebSocket connection URL.

url = server.get_websocket_url()
# Returns: "ws://192.168.1.100:9090"

docs.title: broadcast(message: str)
docs.text:
Send message to all connected clients.

server.broadcast("Hello, clients!")

docs.title: get_client_count() -> int
docs.text:
Get number of connected clients.

count = server.get_client_count()

docs.title: Callbacks
docs.text:
All callbacks can be async or sync functions:

# Async callback
async def on_imu(data: IMUData):
    print(f"IMU: {data}")

# Sync callback
def on_imu(data: IMUData):
    print(f"IMU: {data}")

docs.title: Connection Callbacks
docs.text:
• on_connect(client_id: str) - Client connected
  • on_disconnect(client_id: str) - Client disconnected

docs.title: Sensor Callbacks
docs.text:
• on_handshake(handshake: HandshakeMessage) - Device info received
  • on_imu(data: IMUData) - IMU data received
  • on_gps(data: GPSData) - GPS data received
  • on_pose(data: PoseData) - Pose data received
  • on_camera(frame: CameraFrame) - Camera frame received
  • on_depth(frame: DepthFrame) - Depth frame received
  • on_status(status: dict) - Status message received
  • on_error(error: str, details: str) - Error message received

docs.title: Apple Watch Callbacks
docs.text:
• on_watch_imu(data: WatchIMUData) - Watch IMU data
  • on_watch_attitude(data: WatchAttitudeData) - Watch attitude
  • on_watch_activity(data: WatchMotionActivityData) - Watch activity

docs.title: Protocol Servers
docs.text: All protocol servers inherit from BaseArvosServer and share the same interface.

docs.title: GRPCArvosServer
docs.text:
from arvos.servers import GRPCArvosServer

server = GRPCArvosServer(host="0.0.0.0", port=50051)

docs.title: MQTTArvosServer
docs.text:
from arvos.servers import MQTTArvosServer

server = MQTTArvosServer(host="localhost", port=1883)

docs.title: HTTPArvosServer
docs.text:
from arvos.servers import HTTPArvosServer

server = HTTPArvosServer(port=8080)

docs.title: MCAPStreamServer
docs.text:
from arvos.servers import MCAPStreamServer

server = MCAPStreamServer(
    host="0.0.0.0",
    port=17500,
    output_file="output.mcap"
)

docs.title: QUICArvosServer
docs.text:
from arvos.servers import QUICArvosServer

server = QUICArvosServer(
    host="0.0.0.0",
    port=4433,
    certfile="/path/to/cert.pem",
    keyfile="/path/to/key.key"
)

docs.title: Protocol Servers API
docs.text: Complete API reference for all protocol server implementations.

docs.title: BaseArvosServer
docs.text:
Abstract base class for all protocol servers.

from arvos.servers import BaseArvosServer

class MyServer(BaseArvosServer):
    async def start(self):
        # Start server
        pass

    async def stop(self):
        # Stop server
        pass

    def get_connection_url(self) -> str:
        return "my-protocol://..."

    def get_protocol_name(self) -> str:
        return "My Protocol"

docs.title: Common Methods
docs.text: All servers inherit these methods:

docs.title: get_local_ip() -> str
docs.text: Get the local IP address of this machine.

docs.title: get_statistics() -> dict
docs.text:
Get server statistics.

stats = server.get_statistics()
# Returns: {
#     "protocol": "WebSocket",
#     "running": True,
#     "bytes_received": 12345,
#     "messages_received": 100,
#     "connected_clients": 1
# }

docs.title: reset_statistics()
docs.text: Reset all statistics counters.

docs.title: print_connection_info()
docs.text: Print connection information to console.

docs.title: Common Callbacks
docs.text: All servers support the same callbacks (see Python SDK API).

docs.title: GRPCArvosServer
docs.text:
gRPC protocol server.

from arvos.servers import GRPCArvosServer

server = GRPCArvosServer(host="0.0.0.0", port=50051)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• host (str): Host address (default: "0.0.0.0")
  • port (int): Port number (default: 50051)

docs.title: Methods
docs.text: Same as BaseArvosServer plus: - start() - Start gRPC server - stop() - Stop gRPC server - get_connection_url() - Returns "grpc://<ip>:<port>" - get_protocol_name() - Returns "gRPC"

docs.title: MQTTArvosServer
docs.text:
MQTT protocol server.

from arvos.servers import MQTTArvosServer

server = MQTTArvosServer(host="localhost", port=1883)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• host (str): MQTT broker host
  • port (int): MQTT broker port (default: 1883)

docs.title: Methods
docs.text: Same as BaseArvosServer plus: - start() - Connect to MQTT broker - stop() - Disconnect from broker - get_connection_url() - Returns "mqtt://<host>:<port>/arvos/telemetry" - get_protocol_name() - Returns "MQTT"

docs.title: HTTPArvosServer
docs.text:
HTTP/REST protocol server.

from arvos.servers import HTTPArvosServer

server = HTTPArvosServer(port=8080)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• host (str): Host address (default: "0.0.0.0")
  • port (int): Port number (default: 8080)

docs.title: Methods
docs.text: Same as BaseArvosServer plus: - start() - Start HTTP server - stop() - Stop HTTP server - get_connection_url() - Returns "http://<ip>:<port>/api" - get_protocol_name() - Returns "HTTP"

docs.title: Endpoints
docs.text:
• GET /api/health - Health check
  • POST /api/telemetry - JSON sensor data
  • POST /api/binary - Binary data

docs.title: MCAPStreamServer
docs.text:
MCAP stream protocol server.

from arvos.servers import MCAPStreamServer

server = MCAPStreamServer(
    host="0.0.0.0",
    port=17500,
    output_file="output.mcap"
)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• host (str): Host address (default: "0.0.0.0")
  • port (int): Port number (default: 17500)
  • output_file (str): Output MCAP file path

docs.title: Methods
docs.text: Same as BaseArvosServer plus: - start() - Start MCAP stream server - stop() - Stop server and close MCAP file - get_connection_url() - Returns "mcap://<ip>:<port>" - get_protocol_name() - Returns "MCAP Stream"

docs.title: QUICArvosServer
docs.text:
QUIC/HTTP3 protocol server.

from arvos.servers import QUICArvosServer

server = QUICArvosServer(
    host="0.0.0.0",
    port=4433,
    certfile="/path/to/cert.pem",
    keyfile="/path/to/key.key"
)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• host (str): Host address (default: "0.0.0.0")
  • port (int): Port number (default: 4433)
  • certfile (str): TLS certificate file path
  • keyfile (str): TLS private key file path

docs.title: Methods
docs.text: Same as BaseArvosServer plus: - start() - Start QUIC/HTTP3 server - stop() - Stop server - get_connection_url() - Returns "https://<ip>:<port>/api" - get_protocol_name() - Returns "QUIC/HTTP3" - is_available() -> bool - Check if QUIC is available (static method)

docs.title: Development Guide
docs.text: Set up your development environment for ARVOS SDK.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.8+
  • Git
  • Virtual environment (recommended)

docs.title: 1. Clone Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/jaskirat1616/arvos-sdk.git
cd arvos-sdk

docs.title: 2. Create Virtual Environment
docs.text:
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # Mac/Linux
# OR
venv\Scripts\activate  # Windows

docs.title: 3. Install Dependencies
docs.text: pip install -e ".[dev]"

docs.title: 4. Install Protocol Dependencies
docs.text:
# For all protocols
pip install grpcio grpcio-tools protobuf paho-mqtt bleak mcap aioquic

# Run all tests
pytest

# Run with coverage
pytest --cov=arvos tests/

pytest tests/test_data_types.py

docs.title: Apple Watch Examples
docs.text: Receive and process Apple Watch sensor data.

docs.title: Basic Watch Receiver
docs.text:
import asyncio
from arvos import ArvosServer
from arvos.data_types import WatchIMUData, WatchAttitudeData, WatchMotionActivityData

async def main():
    server = ArvosServer(port=9090)

    # Watch IMU data (50-100 Hz)
    async def on_watch_imu(data: WatchIMUData):
        accel = data.linear_acceleration_array
        gyro = data.angular_velocity_array
        print(f"Watch IMU: accel={accel}, gyro={gyro}")

    # Watch attitude/pose
    async def on_watch_attitude(data: WatchAttitudeData):
        import math
        pitch_deg = math.degrees(data.pitch)
        roll_deg = math.degrees(data.roll)
        yaw_deg = math.degrees(data.yaw)
        print(f"Watch Attitude: pitch={pitch_deg:.1f}°, roll={roll_deg:.1f}°, yaw={yaw_deg:.1f}°")

    # Watch motion activity
    async def on_watch_activity(data: WatchMotionActivityData):
        print(f"Activity: {data.state} (confidence: {data.confidence:.1%})")

    server.on_watch_imu = on_watch_imu
    server.on_watch_attitude = on_watch_attitude
    server.on_watch_activity = on_watch_activity

    await server.start()

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: Basic Server Example
docs.text: Create a simple WebSocket server to receive ARVOS sensor data.

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
import asyncio
from arvos import ArvosServer
from arvos.data_types import IMUData, GPSData, PoseData, CameraFrame, DepthFrame

async def main():
    # Create server
    server = ArvosServer(port=9090)

    # Show QR code for easy connection
    server.print_qr_code()

    # Connection callbacks
    async def on_connect(client_id: str):
        print(f"✅ Client connected: {client_id}")

    async def on_disconnect(client_id: str):
        print(f"👋 Client disconnected: {client_id}")

    # Sensor callbacks
    async def on_handshake(handshake):
        print(f"🤝 Device: {handshake.device_name} ({handshake.device_model})")
        print(f"   OS: {handshake.os_version}, App: {handshake.app_version}")

    async def on_imu(data: IMUData):
        print(f"📊 IMU: accel={data.linear_acceleration}, gyro={data.angular_velocity}")

    async def on_gps(data: GPSData):
        print(f"📍 GPS: {data.latitude:.6f}, {data.longitude:.6f}")

    async def on_pose(data: PoseData):
        print(f"🧭 Pose: position={data.position}, tracking={data.tracking_state}")

    async def on_camera(frame: CameraFrame):
        print(f"📷 Camera: {frame.width}x{frame.height}, {frame.size_kb:.1f} KB")

    async def on_depth(frame: DepthFrame):
        print(f"🔍 Depth: {frame.point_count} points, {frame.size_kb:.1f} KB")

    # Register callbacks
    server.on_connect = on_connect
    server.on_disconnect = on_disconnect
    server.on_handshake = on_handshake
    server.on_imu = on_imu
    server.on_gps = on_gps
    server.on_pose = on_pose
    server.on_camera = on_camera
    server.on_depth = on_depth

    # Start server
    print("🚀 Server started. Waiting for connections...")
    await server.start()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: Run the Example
docs.text: python examples/basic_server.py

docs.title: WebSocket
docs.text:
Default protocol - works everywhere.

import asyncio
from arvos import ArvosServer

async def main():
    server = ArvosServer(port=9090)
    server.print_qr_code()

    server.on_imu = lambda data: print(f"IMU: {data}")
    await server.start()

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: MQTT
docs.text:
IoT-friendly protocol.

First, start broker: 

mosquitto -c mosquitto.conf

Then run server:

async def main():
    server = MQTTArvosServer(host="localhost", port=1883)

    server.on_imu = lambda data: print(f"IMU: {data}")
    await server.start()

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: MCAP Stream
docs.text:
Robotics standard format.

import asyncio
from arvos.servers import MCAPStreamServer

async def main():
    server = MCAPStreamServer(
        host="0.0.0.0",
        port=17500,
        output_file="output.mcap"
    )

    server.on_imu = lambda data: print(f"IMU: {data}")
    await server.start()

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: QUIC/HTTP3
docs.text:
Ultra-low latency protocol.

First, generate certificates: 

openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:2048 \
    -keyout /tmp/arvos-quic.key \
    -out /tmp/arvos-quic-cert.pem \
    -days 365 -nodes

Then run server: 

import asyncio
from arvos.servers import QUICArvosServer

async def main():
    server = QUICArvosServer(
        host="0.0.0.0",
        port=4433,
        certfile="/tmp/arvos-quic-cert.pem",
        keyfile="/tmp/arvos-quic.key"
    )

    server.on_imu = lambda data: print(f"IMU: {data}")
    await server.start()

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: ROS 2 Integration
docs.text: Publish ARVOS sensor data to ROS 2 topics.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The ROS 2 bridge publishes standard ROS messages from ARVOS sensor data.

docs.title: Topics
docs.text: Topic Message Type Description /arvos/imu sensor_msgs/Imu IMU data /arvos/gps sensor_msgs/NavSatFix GPS location /arvos/camera/image_raw sensor_msgs/Image Camera frames /arvos/camera/info sensor_msgs/CameraInfo Camera intrinsics /arvos/depth/points sensor_msgs/PointCloud2 Depth point clouds /arvos/tf tf2_msgs/TFMessage Transform tree

docs.title: Start Bridge
docs.text: python examples/ros2_bridge.py

docs.title: View Topics
docs.text:
# List topics
ros2 topic list

# Echo IMU data
ros2 topic echo /arvos/imu

# Echo GPS data
ros2 topic echo /arvos/gps

docs.title: Visualize in RViz
docs.text:
rviz2

Configure RViz to display: - Camera feed from /arvos/camera/image_raw - Point cloud from /arvos/depth/points - TF tree from /arvos/tf

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import asyncio
from arvos import ArvosServer
import rclpy
from sensor_msgs.msg import Imu, NavSatFix, Image, PointCloud2

async def main():
    rclpy.init()
    node = rclpy.create_node('arvos_bridge')

    # Create publishers
    imu_pub = node.create_publisher(Imu, '/arvos/imu', 10)
    gps_pub = node.create_publisher(NavSatFix, '/arvos/gps', 10)

    server = ArvosServer(port=9090)

    async def on_imu(data):
        msg = Imu()
        # Convert ARVOS IMU to ROS message
        # ... conversion code ...
        imu_pub.publish(msg)

    server.on_imu = on_imu
    await server.start()

asyncio.run(main())

gps_plot = axes[1, 0]
pose_plot = axes[1, 1]

async def main():

    server.on_pose = lambda data: update_pose_plot(data)

    await server.start()

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: First Connection
docs.text: Connect your iPhone to the ARVOS server for the first time.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• ✅ ARVOS Python SDK installed
  • ✅ ARVOS iOS app installed on iPhone
  • ✅ Both devices on same Wi-Fi network
  • ✅ Server running (see Quick Start)

docs.title: 2. Open ARVOS App
docs.text: On your iPhone: 1. Open the ARVOS app 2. Tap "CONNECT TO SERVER" button

docs.title: 3. Select Protocol
docs.text: Choose your protocol: - WebSocket (default) - Works everywhere - gRPC - High performance (iOS 18+) - MQTT - IoT deployments - HTTP/REST - Simple integration - Bluetooth LE - No Wi-Fi needed - MCAP Stream - Robotics research - QUIC/HTTP3 - Ultra-low latency

docs.title: 4. Connect
docs.text:
Option A: Scan QR Code - Point your iPhone camera at the QR code - Tap the notification to open in ARVOS app

Option B: Manual Entry - Tap "Enter Manually" - Enter your computer's IP address (shown in terminal) - Enter port number (default: 9090 for WebSocket) - Tap "CONNECT"

docs.title: 5. Start Streaming
docs.text: Once connected: 1. Tap "START STREAMING" button 2. Select your streaming mode: - Full Sensor - All sensors - RGBD Camera - Camera + Depth - IMU Only - Just IMU data - Mapping - Pose + IMU 3. Watch data flow to your Python server!

docs.title: "Connection Failed"
docs.text:
Check Network: - Ensure both devices on same Wi-Fi - Try pinging iPhone from computer: ping <iphone-ip> - Try pinging computer from iPhone

Check Firewall: - macOS: System Settings → Firewall → Allow Python - Linux: sudo ufw allow 9090 - Windows: Windows Defender → Allow Python

Check Port: 

# Test if port is open
nc -l 9090  # Should listen without errors

docs.title: "QR Code Not Scanning"
docs.text:
• Increase terminal font size
  • Use manual IP entry instead
  • Check QR code contains correct IP

docs.title: "No Data Received"
docs.text:
• Ensure "START STREAMING" is tapped in app
  • Check server callbacks are registered
  • Verify protocol matches (WebSocket, gRPC, etc.)

docs.title: Protocol-Specific Issues
docs.text:
gRPC: - Requires iOS 18+ - Check port 50051 is open

MQTT: - Ensure Mosquitto broker is running - Check broker is listening on all interfaces

HTTP/REST: - Use actual LAN IP (not 0.0.0.0) - Check App Transport Security settings

Bluetooth LE: - Enable Bluetooth on both devices - Ensure app is advertising (BLE toggle on)

→ Full Troubleshooting Guide

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Install the ARVOS Python SDK and all dependencies.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.8 or higher
  • pip (Python package manager)
  • Same Wi-Fi network as your iPhone (for Wi-Fi protocols)

docs.title: From PyPI (Recommended)
docs.text: pip install arvos-sdk

docs.title: From Source
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/jaskirat1616/arvos-sdk.git
cd arvos-sdk
pip install -e .

docs.title: Protocol-Specific Dependencies
docs.text: The core SDK includes WebSocket support. For other protocols, install additional dependencies:

docs.title: gRPC
docs.text: pip install grpcio grpcio-tools protobuf

docs.title: MQTT
docs.text:
pip install paho-mqtt
# Also install Mosquitto broker
brew install mosquitto        # macOS
sudo apt-get install mosquitto  # Linux

docs.title: Bluetooth LE

docs.title: MCAP Stream
docs.text: pip install mcap

docs.title: QUIC/HTTP3
docs.text: pip install aioquic

docs.title: Visualization

docs.title: Image Processing
docs.text: pip install opencv-python pillow

docs.title: ROS 2 Integration
docs.text: pip install rclpy cv_bridge

docs.title: Development

Test your installation:

python -c "import arvos; print(arvos.__version__)"

Should output: 1.0.0

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get started with ARVOS in under 5 minutes!

docs.title: Option 1: Web Viewer (Fastest - 30 seconds)
docs.text:
No Python installation required - works in any browser:

cd arvos-sdk/web-viewer
./start-viewer.sh    # Mac/Linux
# OR
start-viewer.bat     # Windows

Then: 1. Scan the QR code with your iPhone 2. Open the ARVOS app 3. Tap "CONNECT TO SERVER" 4. Tap "START" to stream

→ Full Web Viewer Guide

docs.title: Step 1: Install the SDK
docs.text:
pip install arvos-sdk

Or from source: 

git clone https://github.com/jaskirat1616/arvos-sdk.git
cd arvos-sdk
pip install -e .

docs.title: Step 2: Create a Simple Server
docs.text:
Create a file my_server.py:

import asyncio
from arvos import ArvosServer

async def main():
    server = ArvosServer(port=9090)

    # Show QR code for easy connection
    server.print_qr_code()

    # Define what to do when data arrives
    async def on_imu(data):
        print(f"📊 IMU: accel={data.linear_acceleration}")

    async def on_camera(frame):
        print(f"📷 Camera: {frame.width}x{frame.height}, {frame.size_kb:.1f} KB")

    # Register callbacks
    server.on_imu = on_imu
    server.on_camera = on_camera

    # Start server
    await server.start()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: Step 3: Run the Server
docs.text: python my_server.py

docs.title: Step 4: Connect from iPhone
docs.text:
1. Open the ARVOS app on your iPhone
  2. Tap "CONNECT TO SERVER"
  3. Select WebSocket protocol (default)
  4. Scan the QR code or enter your computer's IP address
  5. Tap "CONNECT"
  6. Tap "START STREAMING"

You should see sensor data appearing in your terminal!

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Can't connect? - Ensure both devices are on the same Wi-Fi network - Check firewall settings (allow port 9090) - Try the Web Viewer instead

QR code not scanning? - Increase terminal font size - Enter IP address manually in the app

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text: Recommended practices for using ARVOS effectively.

docs.title: Use Async Callbacks
docs.text:
Prefer async callbacks for better performance:

# Good
async def on_imu(data: IMUData):
    await process_imu(data)

# Avoid blocking
def on_imu(data: IMUData):
    time.sleep(1)  # Don't block!
    process_imu(data)

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Always handle errors in callbacks:

async def on_camera(frame: CameraFrame):
    try:
        img = frame.to_numpy()
        if img is not None:
            process_image(img)
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Error processing camera frame: {e}")

docs.title: Resource Management
docs.text:
Clean up resources properly:

async def main():
    server = ArvosServer(port=9090)
    try:
        await server.start()
    finally:
        await server.stop()

docs.title: Batch Processing
docs.text:
Batch multiple messages for efficiency:

imu_buffer = []

async def on_imu(data: IMUData):
    imu_buffer.append(data)
    if len(imu_buffer) >= 100:
        process_batch(imu_buffer)
        imu_buffer.clear()

docs.title: Async Processing
docs.text:
Don't block the event loop:

async def on_camera(frame: CameraFrame):
    # Process in background
    asyncio.create_task(heavy_processing(frame))

docs.title: Selective Processing
docs.text:
Only process what you need:

# Only process every Nth frame
frame_count = 0

async def on_camera(frame: CameraFrame):
    global frame_count
    frame_count += 1
    if frame_count % 5 == 0:  # Every 5th frame
        process_frame(frame)

docs.title: Type Safety
docs.text:
Use type hints for better code:

from arvos.data_types import IMUData

async def on_imu(data: IMUData) -> None:
    # Type-safe access
    accel = data.linear_acceleration
    gyro = data.angular_velocity

docs.title: Data Validation
docs.text:
Validate data before processing:

async def on_pose(data: PoseData):
    if not data.is_tracking_good():
        return  # Skip bad tracking

    # Process good tracking data
    process_pose(data)

docs.title: Memory Management
docs.text:
Don't accumulate data indefinitely:

# Good - process and discard
async def on_imu(data: IMUData):
    result = process_imu(data)
    save_result(result)
    # Data is garbage collected

# Bad - accumulates in memory
imu_data_list = []
async def on_imu(data: IMUData):
    imu_data_list.append(data)  # Memory leak!

docs.title: Protocol Selection
docs.text:
Choose the right protocol for your use case:

  • General purpose: WebSocket
  • High performance: gRPC
  • Multiple subscribers: MQTT
  • Simple integration: HTTP/REST
  • No Wi-Fi: Bluetooth LE
  • Robotics: MCAP Stream
  • Ultra-low latency: QUIC/HTTP3

docs.title: Connection Handling
docs.text:
Handle reconnections gracefully:

async def on_disconnect(client_id: str):
    print(f"Client {client_id} disconnected")
    # Clean up resources
    # Prepare for reconnection

async def on_connect(client_id: str):
    print(f"Client {client_id} connected")
    # Initialize resources

docs.title: Local Development
docs.text: For local development: - Use self-signed certificates for QUIC/HTTP3 - Trust certificates on test devices - Use local network only

docs.title: Production
docs.text: For production: - Use proper TLS certificates - Validate all inputs - Implement authentication - Use secure protocols

docs.title: Unit Tests
docs.text:
Test your callbacks:

def test_imu_processing():
    data = IMUData(
        timestamp_ns=1000,
        angular_velocity=(0.1, 0.2, 0.3),
        linear_acceleration=(1.0, 2.0, 3.0)
    )
    result = process_imu(data)
    assert result is not None

docs.title: Integration Tests
docs.text:
Test with real server:

async def test_server():
    server = ArvosServer(port=9090)
    # Test server functionality
    await server.start()
    # ... test ...
    await server.stop()

docs.title: Code Comments
docs.text:
Document complex logic:

async def on_depth(frame: DepthFrame):
    # Parse PLY point cloud format
    # Format: [x, y, z, r, g, b] per point
    points = frame.to_point_cloud()
    if points is not None:
        xyz = points[:, :3]  # Extract 3D positions
        rgb = points[:, 3:]  # Extract RGB colors

docs.title: Type Hints
docs.text:
Use type hints throughout:

from typing import Optional
from arvos.data_types import IMUData

async def process_imu(data: IMUData) -> Optional[dict]:
    # Process and return result
    pass

docs.title: Performance Optimization
docs.text: Optimize your ARVOS setup for maximum performance.

docs.title: Use Wired Connection
docs.text:
• Connect computer via Ethernet
  • Reduces Wi-Fi congestion
  • Lower latency
  • More stable

docs.title: Optimize Wi-Fi
docs.text:
• Use 5 GHz band (if available)
  • Position devices closer
  • Reduce interference
  • Use dedicated network

docs.title: Protocol Selection
docs.text:
• gRPC or QUIC/HTTP3 for maximum performance
  • WebSocket for good balance
  • HTTP/REST not ideal for high-frequency data

docs.title: Async Processing
docs.text:
Process data asynchronously:

async def on_camera(frame):
    # Don't block - process in background
    asyncio.create_task(process_frame(frame))

async def process_frame(frame):
    # Heavy processing here
    img = frame.to_numpy()
    # ... processing ...

docs.title: Skip Frames
docs.text:
For high-frequency data, skip some frames:

frame_count = 0

async def on_camera(frame):
    global frame_count
    frame_count += 1
    if frame_count % 2 == 0:  # Process every 2nd frame
        process_frame(frame)

docs.title: Batch Processing
docs.text:
Batch multiple messages:

imu_buffer = []

async def on_imu(data):
    imu_buffer.append(data)
    if len(imu_buffer) >= 100:
        process_batch(imu_buffer)
        imu_buffer.clear()

docs.title: Reduce Rates in App
docs.text:
• Lower camera frame rate
  • Reduce IMU sample rate
  • Disable unused sensors

docs.title: Selective Streaming
docs.text:
• Use "IMU Only" mode for telemetry
  • Use "RGBD Camera" for 3D reconstruction
  • Custom mode for specific needs

docs.title: Process and Discard
docs.text:
• Don't accumulate data indefinitely
  • Process and discard immediately
  • Use generators for large datasets

docs.title: Downsample Point Clouds
docs.text:
• Reduce point cloud density
  • Filter by distance
  • Use voxel downsampling

docs.title: Use NumPy Operations
docs.text:
• Vectorized operations
  • Avoid Python loops
  • Use compiled libraries

docs.title: Parallel Processing
docs.text:
• Use multiprocessing for heavy tasks
  • Process frames in parallel
  • Utilize all CPU cores

docs.title: Example: Optimized Server
docs.text:
import asyncio
from arvos import ArvosServer
import numpy as np

# Batch processing
imu_buffer = []
BATCH_SIZE = 100

async def process_imu_batch(batch):
    # Vectorized processing
    accels = np.array([d.linear_acceleration for d in batch])
    gyros = np.array([d.angular_velocity for d in batch])
    # Process batch...
    pass

async def main():
    server = ArvosServer(port=9090)

    async def on_imu(data):
        global imu_buffer
        imu_buffer.append(data)
        if len(imu_buffer) >= BATCH_SIZE:
            await process_imu_batch(imu_buffer)
            imu_buffer.clear()

    server.on_imu = on_imu
    await server.start()

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: Protocol Selection Guide
docs.text: Choose the right streaming protocol for your use case.

docs.title: Step 1: Network Available?
docs.text:
No Wi-Fi Available? → Use Bluetooth LE

Wi-Fi Available? → Continue to Step 2

docs.title: Step 2: Performance Requirements
docs.text:
Need Maximum Performance? → Use gRPC (iOS 18+) or QUIC/HTTP3 (iOS 15+)

Standard Performance OK? → Continue to Step 3

docs.title: Step 3: Use Case
docs.text:
Multiple Subscribers Needed? → Use MQTT

Simple Integration / Webhooks? → Use HTTP/REST

Robotics Research / Foxglove? → Use MCAP Stream

General Purpose? → Use WebSocket (default)

docs.title: Use WebSocket When:
docs.text:
• ✅ First-time users
  • ✅ General purpose streaming
  • ✅ Need bidirectional communication
  • ✅ Want simple setup
  • ✅ Standard performance is sufficient

Example: Most research applications, development, testing

docs.title: Use gRPC When:
docs.text:
• ✅ Need maximum performance
  • ✅ iOS 18+ available
  • ✅ High-throughput requirements
  • ✅ Production deployments
  • ✅ Protocol Buffers familiarity

Example: Large-scale data collection, real-time processing

docs.title: Use MQTT When:
docs.text:
• ✅ Multiple subscribers needed
  • ✅ IoT deployment
  • ✅ Broker-based architecture
  • ✅ Distributed processing
  • ✅ Quality of Service needed

Example: Multiple receivers, cloud processing, IoT systems

docs.title: Use HTTP/REST When:
docs.text:
• ✅ Simple webhook integration
  • ✅ REST API compatibility
  • ✅ Easy debugging needed
  • ✅ Cloud function triggers
  • ✅ Simple scripts

Example: Web services, cloud functions, simple integrations

docs.title: Use Bluetooth LE When:
docs.text:
• ✅ No Wi-Fi available
  • ✅ Low power requirements
  • ✅ Telemetry-only use case
  • ✅ Direct device connection
  • ✅ Cable-free operation

Example: Field deployments, low-power scenarios, telemetry only

docs.title: Use MCAP Stream When:
docs.text:
• ✅ Robotics research
  • ✅ Foxglove Studio integration
  • ✅ Standardized format needed
  • ✅ Tool compatibility required
  • ✅ Rich metadata needed

Example: Robotics research, Foxglove visualization, standardized data

docs.title: Use QUIC/HTTP3 When:
docs.text:
• ✅ Ultra-low latency required
  • ✅ Unstable network conditions
  • ✅ Mobile network scenarios
  • ✅ Real-time applications
  • ✅ iOS 15+ available

Example: Real-time control, mobile networks, unstable connections

docs.title: Latency (Lower is Better)
docs.text: QUIC/HTTP3 ≈ gRPC < WebSocket ≈ MCAP ≈ BLE < MQTT ≈ HTTP

docs.title: Throughput (Higher is Better)
docs.text: gRPC ≈ QUIC/HTTP3 > WebSocket ≈ MCAP > MQTT ≈ HTTP > BLE

docs.title: Setup Complexity (Lower is Better)
docs.text: WebSocket ≈ HTTP ≈ BLE ≈ MCAP < MQTT ≈ gRPC < QUIC/HTTP3

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Use Case Recommended Protocol First-time user WebSocket Maximum performance gRPC Multiple subscribers MQTT Simple integration HTTP/REST No Wi-Fi Bluetooth LE Robotics research MCAP Stream Ultra-low latency QUIC/HTTP3

docs.title: Troubleshooting Guide
docs.text: Common issues and solutions for ARVOS.

docs.title: Can't Connect from iPhone
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Connection fails immediately - "Connection Failed" error - Timeout errors

Solutions:

  1. Check Network:
  2. Ensure both devices on same Wi-Fi
  3. Try pinging: ping <iphone-ip>

  4. Verify network connectivity

  5. Check Firewall:

  6. macOS: System Settings → Firewall → Allow Python
  7. Linux: sudo ufw allow <port>

  8. Windows: Windows Defender → Allow Python

  9. Check Port: 

    # Test if port is open
nc -l 9090

  10. Verify Protocol:

  11. Ensure protocol matches server
  12. Check port number
  13. Verify server is running

docs.title: QR Code Not Scanning
docs.text: Solutions: - Increase terminal font size - Use manual IP entry - Check QR code contains correct IP - Ensure good lighting

docs.title: gRPC
docs.text:
• Requires iOS 18+ - Update iOS if needed
  • Check port 50051 is open
  • Verify protobuf code generated

docs.title: MQTT
docs.text:
• Broker must be running: mosquitto -c mosquitto.conf
  • Check broker listening on all interfaces (not just localhost)
  • Verify broker port (default 1883)

docs.title: HTTP/REST
docs.text:
• Use actual LAN IP (not 0.0.0.0)
  • Check App Transport Security settings
  • Verify firewall allows port 8080

docs.title: Bluetooth LE
docs.text:
• Enable Bluetooth on both devices
  • Ensure app is advertising (BLE toggle on)
  • Check Python script has Bluetooth permissions
  • Verify devices are within range (~10m)

docs.title: QUIC/HTTP3
docs.text:
• Generate TLS certificates
  • Install aioquic: pip install aioquic
  • For local testing, install self-signed certificate on iPhone
  • Verify port 4433 is not blocked

docs.title: No Data Received
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Connected but no data - Callbacks not firing - Empty statistics

Solutions:

  1. Check Streaming:
  2. Ensure "START STREAMING" tapped in app
  3. Verify streaming mode selected

  4. Check sensor rates not zero

  5. Check Callbacks:

  6. Verify callbacks registered
  7. Check callback function signatures

  8. Ensure async/sync matches

  9. Check Protocol:

  10. Verify protocol matches server
  11. Check server is receiving data
  12. Review server logs

docs.title: Incomplete Data
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Missing sensor types - Partial messages - Corrupted data

Solutions:

  1. Check Streaming Mode:
  2. Verify mode includes desired sensors
  3. Check sensor availability on device

  4. Review mode configuration

  5. Check Network:

  6. Network instability can cause data loss
  7. Try different protocol

  8. Check signal strength

  9. Check Bandwidth:

  10. High-frequency data may overwhelm network
  11. Reduce sensor rates
  12. Use lower quality settings

docs.title: High Latency
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Delayed data arrival - Lag in visualization - Stale timestamps

Solutions:

  1. Network:
  2. Use wired connection for computer
  3. Optimize Wi-Fi settings

  4. Try QUIC/HTTP3 protocol

  5. Protocol:

  6. Use gRPC for maximum performance
  7. Avoid HTTP/REST for high-frequency data

  8. Consider QUIC/HTTP3

  9. Processing:

  10. Process data asynchronously
  11. Don't block in callbacks
  12. Use batch processing

docs.title: Dropped Frames
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Missing camera frames - Incomplete point clouds - Gaps in data

Solutions:

  1. Reduce Rates:
  2. Lower camera frame rate
  3. Reduce sensor frequencies

  4. Disable unused sensors

  5. Network:

  6. Improve Wi-Fi signal
  7. Use wired connection

  8. Try different protocol

  9. Processing:

  10. Process frames faster
  11. Skip some frames if needed
  12. Use async processing

docs.title: High CPU Usage
docs.text:
Solutions:

  1. Optimize Code:
  2. Use NumPy vectorized operations
  3. Process asynchronously

  4. Batch operations

  5. Reduce Processing:

  6. Skip unnecessary processing
  7. Downsample data

  8. Use lower quality

  9. Protocol:

  10. Use efficient protocols (gRPC)
  11. Avoid HTTP for high-frequency data

docs.title: MQTT: Broker Issues
docs.text:
Problem: "Connection refused"

Solution: 

# Check broker is running
ps aux | grep mosquitto

# Check broker config
cat mosquitto.conf
# Should have: listener 1883 0.0.0.0

docs.title: gRPC: Version Issues
docs.text:
Problem: "Method not implemented"

Solution: - Regenerate protobuf code - Check grpcio version compatibility - Verify iOS 18+ on device

docs.title: QUIC/HTTP3: Certificate Issues
docs.text:
Problem: "Certificate verification failed"

Solution: - Generate valid certificates - Install certificate on iPhone - For local testing, trust self-signed cert

docs.title: BLE: Connection Issues
docs.text:
Problem: "Device not found"

Solution: - Ensure app is advertising - Check Bluetooth is enabled - Verify devices are nearby - Restart Bluetooth on both devices

docs.text:

  • Include:
  • Protocol used

  • Network setup
  • Device information

docs.title: Apple Watch Integration
docs.text: Stream wearable sensor data from your Apple Watch alongside iPhone sensors.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The ARVOS app supports Apple Watch as a companion device, streaming wearable IMU, attitude, and motion activity data in sync with iPhone sensors.

docs.title: Apple Watch
docs.text:
• Apple Watch Series 6 or newer
  • watchOS 9.0+
  • Paired with streaming iPhone

docs.title: iPhone
docs.text:
• Same requirements as main app
  • Watch app installed (installs automatically)

docs.title: Step 1: Build iOS App
docs.text: The Watch app is included in the iOS app project: 1. Open Xcode project 2. Build for iPhone 3. Watch app installs automatically on paired watch

docs.text:
1. Open ARVOS app on iPhone
  2. Go to Settings
  3. Find "Apple Watch" section
  4. Toggle "Enable Watch Streaming"

docs.title: Step 3: Verify Connection
docs.text:
1. Check connection indicator (should show green)
  2. Open Sensor Test view
  3. Toggle "Apple Watch" on
  4. Watch data should appear

docs.title: IMU Data
docs.text:
• Rate: 50-100 Hz
  • Sensors: Accelerometer, gyroscope, gravity
  • Synchronization: Nanosecond timestamps
  • Format: Same as iPhone IMU

docs.title: Attitude Data
docs.text:
• Quaternion: x, y, z, w
  • Euler Angles: Pitch, roll, yaw
  • Reference Frame: Configurable
  • Rate: 50-100 Hz

docs.title: Motion Activity
docs.text:
• States: Walking, running, cycling, vehicle, stationary, unknown
  • Confidence: 0.0 - 1.0
  • Updates: Real-time classification

docs.title: Enable in Streaming
docs.text:
1. Start streaming session
  2. Watch data automatically included
  3. Data flows through same protocol as iPhone data
  4. Tagged with sensorType: "watch_imu", etc.

docs.title: View in Sensor Test
docs.text:
1. Open Sensor Test view
  2. Toggle "Apple Watch" section
  3. View real-time watch data
  4. Monitor sample rates

docs.title: Recording
docs.text: Watch data is automatically included in MCAP recordings: - Same timestamp synchronization - Same file format - All watch sensors preserved

docs.title: Synchronization
docs.text: Watch data is synchronized with iPhone sensors: - Nanosecond timestamps - Precise synchronization - Same protocol - Flows through same connection - Same format - Consistent data structure

docs.title: App Availability
docs.text: The ARVOS iOS app is available for download and use on the App Store. The app provides a full-featured sensor streaming platform for iPhone and Apple Watch.

docs.title: Source Code Status
docs.text:
Private Repository

The iOS app source code is not open source and is not publicly available on GitHub. The app is distributed through the App Store as a compiled binary.

docs.title: What This Means
docs.text:
• ✅ App is available - Download and use the app from the App Store
  • ✅ Full functionality - All features work as documented
  • ✅ SDK is open source - Python SDK code is fully open source
  • ❌ App code is private - iOS app source code is not available

docs.title: Why Keep It Private?
docs.text: The iOS app source code is kept private for: - Intellectual property protection - Commercial considerations - Code quality control - Security and stability

docs.title: What You Can Do
docs.text: Even though the app code is private, you can: - ✅ Use the app fully (all features work) - ✅ Contribute to the Python SDK (fully open source) - ✅ Report bugs and request features - ✅ Use all protocols and features - ✅ Integrate with your own systems

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
If you want to contribute: - Python SDK: Fully open source - contributions welcome! - Documentation: Help improve docs - Examples: Add more examples - Bug Reports: Report issues you find

→ Contributing Guide

docs.title: Support
docs.text:
For app-related questions: - Check the Usage Guide - Review Troubleshooting - Open an issue on the SDK repository

The SDK repository is the primary support channel for both the app and SDK.

docs.title: iOS App Overview
docs.text:
The ARVOS iOS app turns your iPhone (and optional Apple Watch) into a professional sensor streaming platform.

App Availability

The ARVOS iOS app is available on the App Store for download and use. However, the iOS app source code is not open source and is not publicly available on GitHub. This documentation covers app usage and features.

docs.title: 📱 iPhone Sensors
docs.text:
• 📷 Camera: 30 FPS @ 1920x1080 RGB video streaming
  • 🔍 LiDAR/Depth: 5 FPS 3D point clouds with confidence maps
  • 📊 IMU: 100-200 Hz accelerometer + gyroscope + gravity reference
  • 🧭 ARKit Pose: 30-60 Hz 6DOF camera tracking with quality flags
  • 📍 GPS: 1 Hz location data (outdoor)

docs.title: ⌚ Apple Watch Integration
docs.text:
• ⌚ IMU: 50-100 Hz wearable accelerometer + gyroscope + gravity
  • 🧭 Attitude: Quaternion + pitch/roll/yaw angles
  • 🚶 Motion Activity: Classification (walking, running, cycling, vehicle, stationary)

docs.title: 🌐 7 Streaming Protocols
docs.text:
Choose the protocol that fits your use case:

  • WebSocket - General purpose, default
  • gRPC - High performance, research (iOS 18+)
  • MQTT - IoT, multi-subscriber
  • HTTP/REST - Simple integration
  • Bluetooth LE - Low bandwidth, cable-free
  • MCAP Stream - Robotics research
  • QUIC/HTTP3 - Ultra-low latency (iOS 15+)

docs.title: 📊 Streaming Modes
docs.text:
• Full Sensor - All available sensors
  • RGBD Camera - Camera + Depth only
  • IMU Only - Just IMU data (low bandwidth)
  • Mapping - Pose + IMU (SLAM use cases)
  • Visual-Inertial - Camera + IMU
  • LiDAR - Depth + IMU
  • Custom - Configure your own sensor combination

docs.text:

  • H.264 video encoding
  • Nanosecond timestamps
  • Export to KITTI, TUM, EuRoC formats

docs.text:
• iPhone 12 Pro or newer (for LiDAR)
  • iOS 16.0+ (iOS 18+ for gRPC)
  • Same Wi-Fi network as computer (or Bluetooth for BLE)

docs.title: Apple Watch (Optional)
docs.text:
• Apple Watch Series 6 or newer
  • watchOS 9.0+
  • Paired with streaming iPhone

docs.text:

docs.title: Protocol Selection in iOS App
docs.text: How to select and configure streaming protocols in the ARVOS iOS app.

docs.title: Protocol Picker
docs.text:
The app includes a protocol picker in the connection sheet:

  1. Open "CONNECT TO SERVER"
  2. Find the "PROTOCOL" section
  3. Select your desired protocol from the segmented control

docs.title: WebSocket (Default)
docs.text:
When to use: - General purpose streaming - First time users - Most use cases

Configuration: - Host: Your computer's IP address - Port: 9090 (default)

docs.title: gRPC
docs.text:
When to use: - High-performance research applications - Need Protocol Buffers efficiency - iOS 18+ available

Configuration: - Host: Your computer's IP address - Port: 50051 (default) - Note: Requires iOS 18+

docs.title: MQTT
docs.text:
When to use: - Multiple subscribers needed - IoT deployments - Broker-based architecture

Configuration: - Host: MQTT broker IP address - Port: 1883 (default) - Note: Requires MQTT broker running

docs.title: HTTP/REST
docs.text:
When to use: - Simple webhook integrations - REST API compatibility - Easy debugging

Configuration: - Host: Your computer's IP address - Port: 8080 (default)

docs.title: Bluetooth LE
docs.text:
When to use: - No Wi-Fi available - Low power requirements - Telemetry-only use cases

Configuration: - No host/port needed - App automatically advertises - Python script discovers device

docs.title: MCAP Stream
docs.text:
When to use: - Robotics research - Foxglove Studio integration - Standardized data format

Configuration: - Host: Your computer's IP address - Port: 17500 (default)

docs.title: QUIC/HTTP3
docs.text:
When to use: - Ultra-low latency requirements - Unstable network conditions - Mobile network scenarios

Configuration: - Host: Your computer's IP address - Port: 4433 (default) - Note: Requires TLS certificates

docs.title: Protocol-Specific Settings
docs.text: Some protocols have additional settings:

docs.title: MQTT
docs.text:
• Client ID: Auto-generated or custom
  • Topics: Telemetry and binary topics

docs.title: Bluetooth LE
docs.text: • Device Name: Your iPhone's name (auto-detected)

docs.title: QUIC/HTTP3
docs.text: • TLS: Automatically enabled (required)

docs.title: Connection Process
docs.text:
1. Select Protocol - Choose from protocol picker
  2. Enter Host - Computer's IP address (or scan QR code)
  3. Enter Port - Protocol default port (auto-filled)
  4. Tap CONNECT - Establish connection
  5. Tap START - Begin streaming

docs.title: Protocol Not Available
docs.text:
gRPC: - Requires iOS 18+ - Update iOS if needed

docs.title: iOS App Usage Guide
docs.text: Complete guide to using the ARVOS iOS app.

docs.title: Permissions
docs.text:
On first launch, the app will request permissions:

  1. Camera - Required for camera streaming
  2. Location - Required for GPS data
  3. Motion & Fitness - Required for IMU data
  4. Bluetooth - Required for BLE and Apple Watch

Grant all permissions for full functionality.

docs.title: Initial Setup
docs.text:
1. Open the ARVOS app
  2. Review the welcome screen
  3. Grant necessary permissions
  4. Ready to connect!

docs.title: Step 1: Start Your Server
docs.text:
On your computer, start a Python server:

python examples/basic_server.py

docs.title: Step 2: Open Connection Sheet
docs.text: In the ARVOS app: 1. Tap "CONNECT TO SERVER" button 2. Connection sheet appears

docs.title: Step 3: Select Protocol
docs.text:
1. Find "PROTOCOL" section
  2. Select your protocol (WebSocket is default)
  3. Port number auto-fills based on protocol

docs.title: Step 4: Enter Server Details
docs.text:
Option A: Scan QR Code - Point camera at QR code shown in terminal - Tap notification to open in app

Option B: Manual Entry - Tap "Enter Manually" - Enter computer's IP address - Verify port number - Tap "CONNECT"

docs.title: Step 5: Start Streaming
docs.text: Once connected: 1. Tap "START STREAMING" button 2. Select streaming mode 3. Data flows to your server!

docs.title: Full Sensor
docs.text:
Stream all available sensors: - Camera - Depth/LiDAR - IMU - ARKit Pose - GPS

Best for: Complete data collection

docs.title: RGBD Camera
docs.text:
Camera + Depth only: - RGB video - Depth point clouds

Best for: 3D reconstruction

docs.title: IMU Only
docs.text:
Just IMU data: - Accelerometer - Gyroscope - Gravity

Best for: Low bandwidth, high frequency

docs.title: Mapping
docs.text:
Pose + IMU: - ARKit pose - IMU data

Best for: SLAM algorithms

docs.title: Visual-Inertial
docs.text:
Camera + IMU: - RGB video - IMU data

Best for: Sensor fusion

docs.title: LiDAR
docs.text:
Depth + IMU: - Point clouds - IMU data

Best for: 3D scanning

docs.title: Custom
docs.text: Configure your own combination: - Select individual sensors - Set rates - Custom configuration

docs.title: Start Recording
docs.text:
1. Tap "RECORD" button
  2. Select recording location
  3. Recording starts
  4. Tap "STOP" when done

docs.title: Recording Format
docs.text:
• Format: MCAP
  • Video: H.264 encoded
  • Timestamps: Nanosecond precision
  • Metadata: All sensor metadata preserved

docs.title: Export Options
docs.text: Recorded files can be exported to: - KITTI format - TUM format - EuRoC format - PLY point clouds - CSV data

docs.title: Enable Watch
docs.text:
1. Open Settings
  2. Find "Apple Watch" section
  3. Toggle "Enable Watch Streaming"
  4. Ensure watch is paired and nearby

docs.title: Watch Data
docs.text:
Once enabled, watch data streams alongside iPhone data: - Watch IMU (50-100 Hz) - Watch attitude - Motion activity

→ Apple Watch Guide

docs.title: Sensor Test View
docs.text:
Test individual sensors:

  1. Open "Sensor Test" view
  2. Toggle sensors on/off
  3. View real-time data
  4. Monitor sample rates

docs.title: Available Tests
docs.text:
• IMU - Accelerometer, gyroscope, gravity
  • Camera - Live camera preview
  • Depth - Point cloud visualization
  • Pose - ARKit tracking visualization
  • GPS - Location display
  • Apple Watch - Watch sensor data

docs.title: Connection Issues
docs.text:
• Check Wi-Fi network
  • Verify firewall settings
  • Try different protocol
  • Check server is running

docs.title: No Data Streaming
docs.text:

  • Check streaming mode selection
  • Verify server callbacks registered
  • Check protocol matches

docs.title: Performance Issues

  • Use lower quality settings
  • Try different protocol
  • Check network signal

docs.title: Bluetooth LE Protocol
docs.text: Low-bandwidth, cable-free protocol - perfect when Wi-Fi isn't available.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) provides: - ✅ No Wi-Fi needed - ✅ Low power consumption - ✅ Cable-free operation - ✅ Direct device-to-device

docs.title: Python
docs.text: pip install bleak

docs.title: Permissions
docs.text:
• Bluetooth enabled on both devices
  • Bluetooth permissions granted

docs.title: Python Receiver
docs.text:
import asyncio
from arvos.examples.ble_receiver import main

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: iOS App
docs.text:
1. Open ARVOS app
  2. Select Bluetooth LE protocol
  3. App automatically starts advertising
  4. Python script discovers and connects

docs.title: No Wi-Fi Required
docs.text:
• Direct Bluetooth connection
  • Works anywhere
  • No network setup

docs.title: Low Power
docs.text:
• BLE is power-efficient
  • Longer battery life
  • Suitable for mobile use

docs.title: Automatic Discovery
docs.text:
• Python script scans for device
  • Connects automatically
  • No manual pairing needed

docs.title: Low Bandwidth
docs.text:
• Telemetry only (IMU, GPS, Pose)
  • No camera/depth (too large for BLE)
  • Maximum ~20 KB/s throughput

docs.title: Range
docs.text:
• Limited to ~10 meters
  • Line of sight helps
  • Walls reduce range

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Field deployments without Wi-Fi
  • Low power requirements
  • Telemetry-only applications
  • Cable-free setups

docs.title: Data Format
docs.text:
BLE uses length-prefixed messages: 

[Length (2 bytes)][JSON Data]

Messages are automatically chunked and reassembled.

docs.text: See BLE Example

docs.title: WebSocket
docs.text:
Best for: General purpose, first-time users

Pros: - Works everywhere - Bidirectional - Good performance - Easy setup

Cons: - Not the fastest - Single connection per client

Best for: High-performance research

Pros: - Very high performance - Protocol Buffers - Type-safe - Industry standard

Cons: - Requires iOS 18+ - More complex setup - Learning curve

docs.title: MQTT
docs.text:
Best for: IoT, multiple subscribers

Pros: - Multi-subscriber - IoT-friendly - Reliable delivery - Standard protocol

Cons: - Requires broker - Additional infrastructure - Broker can bottleneck

docs.text:
Best for: Simple integration, webhooks

Pros: - Very simple - Easy debugging - Universal compatibility - Webhook support

Cons: - Not bidirectional - Higher overhead - Not ideal for high-frequency

Cons: - Larger files - More complex format - Requires MCAP tools

docs.title: gRPC Protocol
docs.text: High-performance protocol using Protocol Buffers - ideal for research applications.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: gRPC is an industry-standard RPC framework that provides: - ✅ Very high performance - ✅ Protocol Buffers (efficient binary format) - ✅ Bidirectional streaming - ✅ Type-safe interfaces

docs.title: iOS
docs.text:
• iOS 18.0 or higher
  • gRPC support built-in

docs.title: Python
docs.text: pip install grpcio grpcio-tools protobuf

docs.title: Python Server
docs.text:
import asyncio
from arvos.servers import GRPCArvosServer

async def main():
    server = GRPCArvosServer(host="0.0.0.0", port=50051)

    server.on_imu = lambda data: print(f"IMU: {data}")
    await server.start()

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: iOS App
docs.text:
1. Open ARVOS app
  2. Select gRPC protocol
  3. Enter server IP and port 50051
  4. Connect!

docs.title: Protocol Buffers
docs.text:
• Efficient binary serialization
  • Type-safe message definitions
  • Smaller payload sizes
  • Faster encoding/decoding

docs.title: Bidirectional Streaming
docs.text:
• iPhone streams sensor data
  • Server can send control messages
  • Full duplex communication

docs.title: High Performance
docs.text:
• Lower latency than WebSocket
  • Higher throughput
  • Better CPU efficiency

docs.title: Message Format
docs.text:
gRPC uses Protocol Buffers defined in sensors.proto:

message SensorMessage {
    uint64 timestamp_ns = 1;
    oneof data {
        IMUData imu = 11;
        GPSData gps = 12;
        PoseData pose = 13;
        // ... etc
    }
    bytes binary_data = 100;
}

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• High-performance research applications
  • Large-scale data collection
  • Real-time processing pipelines
  • Production deployments

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• ✅ Very high performance
  • ✅ Efficient binary format
  • ✅ Industry standard
  • ✅ Type-safe

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• ⚠️ Requires iOS 18+
  • ⚠️ More complex setup
  • ⚠️ Protocol Buffers learning curve

docs.text: See gRPC Example

docs.title: MQTT Protocol
docs.text: IoT-friendly protocol with multi-subscriber support - perfect for distributed systems.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: MQTT (Message Queuing Telemetry Transport) provides: - ✅ Multi-subscriber support - ✅ IoT-friendly architecture - ✅ Broker-based messaging - ✅ Quality of Service levels

docs.title: Default Port
docs.text: 1883 (broker port)

docs.title: MQTT Broker
docs.text:
Install and start Mosquitto:

# macOS
brew install mosquitto
mosquitto -c mosquitto.conf

# Linux
sudo apt-get install mosquitto
mosquitto -c mosquitto.conf

docs.title: Python
docs.text: pip install paho-mqtt

docs.title: Broker Configuration
docs.text:
Create mosquitto.conf:

listener 1883 0.0.0.0
allow_anonymous true

docs.title: Start Broker
docs.text: mosquitto -c mosquitto.conf

docs.title: QUIC/HTTP3 Protocol
docs.text: Ultra-low latency protocol - perfect for real-time applications and unstable networks.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: QUIC/HTTP3 provides: - ✅ Ultra-low latency - ✅ Better performance on unstable networks - ✅ Built-in encryption (TLS) - ✅ Connection migration

docs.title: iOS
docs.text:
• iOS 15.0 or higher
  • HTTP/3 support built-in

docs.title: Python
docs.text: pip install aioquic

docs.title: TLS Certificates
docs.text:
QUIC requires TLS certificates. For local development:

openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:2048 \
    -keyout /tmp/arvos-quic.key \
    -out /tmp/arvos-quic-cert.pem \
    -days 365 -nodes

docs.title: Python Server
docs.text:
import asyncio
from arvos.servers import QUICArvosServer

async def main():
    server = QUICArvosServer(
        host="0.0.0.0",
        port=4433,
        certfile="/tmp/arvos-quic-cert.pem",
        keyfile="/tmp/arvos-quic.key"
    )

    server.on_imu = lambda data: print(f"IMU: {data}")
    await server.start()

asyncio.run(main())

  4. Connect!

Note: For local testing, you may need to install the self-signed certificate on your iPhone.

  • Secure by default

docs.title: Python SDK Installation
docs.text: Install the ARVOS Python SDK and all dependencies.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.8 or higher
  • pip (Python package manager)

docs.title: From PyPI (Recommended)
docs.text: pip install arvos-sdk

docs.title: From Source
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/jaskirat1616/arvos-sdk.git
cd arvos-sdk
pip install -e .

docs.title: Core (WebSocket)
docs.text: Included with base installation: - websockets>=11.0 - qrcode[pil]>=7.4 - numpy>=1.20.0

docs.title: gRPC
docs.text: pip install grpcio grpcio-tools protobuf

docs.title: MQTT
docs.text:
pip install paho-mqtt
# Also install Mosquitto broker
brew install mosquitto        # macOS
sudo apt-get install mosquitto  # Linux

docs.title: Bluetooth LE
docs.text: pip install bleak

docs.title: MCAP Stream
docs.text: pip install mcap

docs.title: QUIC/HTTP3
docs.text: pip install aioquic

docs.title: Visualization
docs.text: pip install matplotlib pillow

docs.title: Image Processing
docs.text: pip install opencv-python pillow

docs.title: ROS 2 Integration
docs.text: pip install rclpy cv_bridge

docs.title: Development
docs.text: pip install pytest black flake8

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
python -c "import arvos; print(arvos.__version__)"

Should output: 1.0.0

docs.title: Python SDK Overview
docs.text: The ARVOS Python SDK provides a complete toolkit for receiving and processing sensor data from the ARVOS iOS app.

docs.title: Base Server Class
docs.text:
All protocol servers inherit from BaseArvosServer:

from arvos.servers import BaseArvosServer

class MyServer(BaseArvosServer):
    async def start(self):
        # Start server
        pass

    async def stop(self):
        # Stop server
        pass

    def get_connection_url(self) -> str:
        return "my-protocol://..."

    def get_protocol_name(self) -> str:
        return "My Protocol"

docs.title: Unified Callback Interface
docs.text:
All servers share the same callback interface:

server.on_connect = lambda client_id: print(f"Connected: {client_id}")
server.on_imu = lambda data: print(f"IMU: {data}")
server.on_camera = lambda frame: print(f"Camera: {frame}")
# ... etc

docs.title: Protocol Servers
docs.text:
• ArvosServer - WebSocket (default)
  • GRPCArvosServer - gRPC
  • MQTTArvosServer - MQTT
  • HTTPArvosServer - HTTP/REST
  • MCAPStreamServer - MCAP Stream
  • QUICArvosServer - QUIC/HTTP3

docs.title: Client Class
docs.text:
For connecting to existing servers:

from arvos import ArvosClient

client = ArvosClient()
await client.connect("ws://192.168.1.100:9090")
await client.run()

docs.title: Data Types
docs.text:
All sensor data is provided as typed dataclasses:

  • IMUData - IMU sensor data
  • GPSData - GPS location data
  • PoseData - ARKit pose data
  • CameraFrame - Camera frame data
  • DepthFrame - Depth/LiDAR data
  • WatchIMUData - Apple Watch IMU
  • WatchAttitudeData - Apple Watch attitude
  • WatchMotionActivityData - Watch motion activity

→ Complete Data Types Reference

docs.title: Multi-Protocol Support
docs.text:
• 7 streaming protocols
  • Unified API across all protocols
  • Easy protocol switching

docs.title: Type Safety
docs.text:
• Typed dataclasses
  • Type hints throughout
  • IDE autocomplete support

docs.title: Async/Await
docs.text:
• Fully async API
  • Non-blocking I/O
  • High performance

docs.title: Extensible
docs.text:
• Easy to add new protocols
  • Custom callback handlers
  • Plugin architecture

docs.title: Python SDK Quick Start
docs.text: Create your first ARVOS server in 5 minutes.

docs.title: Basic Server
docs.text:
Create a file my_server.py:

import asyncio
from arvos import ArvosServer

async def main():
    # Create server
    server = ArvosServer(port=9090)

    # Show QR code for easy connection
    server.print_qr_code()

    # Define callbacks
    async def on_connect(client_id: str):
        print(f"✅ Client connected: {client_id}")

    async def on_imu(data):
        print(f"📊 IMU: accel={data.linear_acceleration}")

    async def on_camera(frame):
        print(f"📷 Camera: {frame.width}x{frame.height}")

    # Register callbacks
    server.on_connect = on_connect
    server.on_imu = on_imu
    server.on_camera = on_camera

    # Start server
    await server.start()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: Run the Server
docs.text: python my_server.py

docs.title: Connect from iPhone
docs.text:
1. Open ARVOS app
  2. Tap "CONNECT TO SERVER"
  3. Scan QR code or enter IP
  4. Tap "START STREAMING"

Data should start flowing!

docs.title: Web Viewer Overview
docs.text: Zero-install browser-based viewer for ARVOS sensor data.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• ✅ No Python Required - Works in any browser
  • ✅ 30 Second Setup - Start in under a minute
  • ✅ Live Visualization - Real-time sensor data display
  • ✅ Works Everywhere - Any device with a browser

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
cd arvos-sdk/web-viewer
./start-viewer.sh    # Mac/Linux
# OR
start-viewer.bat     # Windows

Then scan the QR code with your iPhone!

→ Quick Start Guide

docs.title: What It Shows
docs.text:
• Camera Feed - Live RGB video
  • Point Cloud - 3D LiDAR visualization
  • IMU Data - Accelerometer and gyroscope
  • GPS - Location on map
  • Pose - ARKit tracking visualization

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Quick testing without SDK setup
  • Live demos and presentations
  • Students and researchers
  • Any device with a browser
  • Zero-install scenarios

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Quick Start - Get started in 30 seconds
  • Web Viewer README - Full documentation

docs.title: Web Viewer Quick Start
docs.text: Get started with the ARVOS Web Viewer in 30 seconds.

docs.title: Step 1: Start the Viewer
docs.text:
cd arvos-sdk/web-viewer
./start-viewer.sh    # Mac/Linux
# OR
start-viewer.bat     # Windows

docs.title: Step 2: Scan QR Code
docs.text: A QR code will appear in your terminal. Scan it with your iPhone camera.

docs.title: Step 3: Connect
docs.text:
1. Tap the notification to open in ARVOS app
  2. Or manually open ARVOS app
  3. Tap "CONNECT TO SERVER"
  4. Tap "START STREAMING"

docs.title: Step 4: View Data
docs.text:
Open your browser to the URL shown in terminal (usually http://localhost:8765).

You'll see: - Live camera feed - Point cloud visualization - IMU data graphs - GPS location - ARKit pose tracking

docs.title: That's It!
docs.text: No Python installation needed. Works on any device with a browser.
